title: Today’s Logistics Report: Trucking Market Toll; Shipping’s Green Debate; China’s Tech Reboot
text:
Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

The gap between trucking’s haves and have-nots is getting wider. Trucking company failures more than tripled in the first half of 2019 from a year ago as the tide rushing out from last year’s freight surge leaves some carriers financially vulnerable, the WSJ Logistics Report’s Jennifer Smith writes. The closures pulled more than 20,000 trucks from the road, according to Broughton Capital LLC, as truckers contend with softening demand and falling spot-market rates. The closures are taking out somewhat bigger operators than last year. But most are relatively small operators with regional footprints, and their demise could help the largest carriers gain more pricing power and control in the marketplace. In the biggest recent failure, Denver-based HVH Transportation Inc.’s closure left about 150 drivers and their cargo stranded. The former CEO says he is working to get drivers home, and cites rising insurance rates as a factor.

TRANSPORTATION

Pressure for the maritime world to act more aggressively to cut emissions is growing. French President Emmanuel Macron is doubling down on his call for container-line operators to cut greenhouse gas emissions by reducing their speed on the water, the WSJ Logistics Report’s Costas Paris writes, ahead of a November meeting where international regulators are set to discuss the divisive tactic. Asian and South American nations in the International Maritime Organization aren’t on board with France’s “slow steaming” mandate, which has the backing of some European countries but would likely increase shipping times and transport costs. Maritime fuel consumption and CO2 emissions have dropped over the past decade as average vessel speeds slowed, but some say mandatory speed reductions would only delay investments in greener technologies in an industry that contributes up to 3% of the world’s greenhouse gas pollution.

China is taking a magnifying glass to its tech-sector supply chains as the trade war with the U.S. intensifies. Beijing is canvassing smartphone maker Xiamoi Corp. and others on their reliance on American suppliers as it readies a retaliatory blacklist of foreign businesses. The WSJ’s Yoko Kubota reports the exercise is part of a larger effort to wean China’s supply chains off dependence on U.S. technology. American-made semiconductors, modems and jet engines are a mainstay for many Chinese companies whose dependence is drawing fresh attention as trade tensions surge. Washington barred U.S. companies from doing business with Chinese telecom gear maker ZTE Corp. last year, and the Beijing blacklist follows American efforts to shut out telecommunications giant Huawei Technologies Co. The survey demonstrates the care Beijing is taking to ensure local players don’t become collateral damage in the trade war, but also reflects the fragility in China’s economic outlook.

The Logistics Report won’t publish on Monday, Sept. 2 because of the Labor Day holiday. The next edition will be on Tuesday, Sept. 3.

QUOTABLE

“ If more ships are added to compensate for slow steaming, it will cost significantly more to move cargo and I don’t know how this will help the environment. ” —Jonathan Gold, the National Retail Federation’s vice president of supply chain and customs policy.

Number of the Day 18.9% Year-over-year decline in U.S. exports to China by value in the first six months of 2019, according to the Commerce Department.

IN OTHER NEWS

Hurricane Dorian is forecast to grow into a Category 4 hurricane as it approaches the Bahamas and Florida. (WSJ)

U.S. economic growth slowed to 2% in the second quarter, in part on weaker inventory investment than earlier reported. (WSJ)

More American companies are losing sales in China as the trade war intensifies. (WSJ)

Bankruptcies are rising in the U.S. oil patch as investors question the shale business. (WSJ)

Quarterly sales rose at discount chains Dollar General Corp. and Dollar Tree Inc. (WSJ)

Best Buy Co. narrowed its 2019 outlook, citing the impact of U.S. tariffs on Chinese-made goods. (WSJ)

Farm-equipment maker Deere & Co.’s chief operating officer will succeed Chief Executive Samuel Allen. (WSJ)

Nippon Steel Corp. is cutting its three-year capital spending plan by 10% because of slowing demand from trade tensions. (Nikkei Asian Review)

Target Corp. told its suppliers they and not the retailer must absorb the costs of higher tariffs. (Oregon Public Broadcasting)

Fashion retailer Forever 21 is preparing a potential bankruptcy filing. (Bloomberg)

The Baltic Dry Index measuring bulk-shipping rates climbed 25.1% this month to a six-year high. (Lloyd’s List)

Agility Logistics’s venture-capital arm will invest $18 million in green supply chain technologies. (The Loadstar)

FedEx Corp. will buy Bogota-based freight forwarder Cargex S.A. (DC Velocity)

Norfolk Southern Corp. appointed United Technologies Corp. executive Mark George chief financial officer. (Progressive Railroading)

A Los Angeles production company will host live e-sports events in converted heavy-duty tractor-trailers. (Los Angeles Business Journal)
